ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MAJLIS UGAMA ISLAM SINGAPURA
(Management of new mosques)


    1. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for Social Affairs what plans the Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura will implement to ensure that the new mosques in the housing estates will be efficiently managed and that the mosques will be utilised for broader community and educational purposes as well.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Encik Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Administration of Muslim Law Act, one of the responsibilities of the Majlis Ugama

Column: 912

Islam Singapura is the administration of all mosques in Singapore. When the new mosques are ready, the Majlis will appoint Mosque Management Committees to look after them and to plan and oversee their programmes and activities. Such Committees will comprise residents from the housing estates in which the mosques are sited and who are capable and willing to render their services.

    All the new mosques to be built under the Mosque Building Fund Scheme implemented by the Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura with the assistance of the Government are constructed as large multi-purpose mosques. They will have ample facilities such as conference rooms, libraries, halls for social

Column: 913

gatherings and other purposes, classrooms and even washing rooms for the dead. Each mosque is a religious complex in itself, designed for use not only for religious purposes but for community programmes as well. The facilities in the mosque will be made available to the residents within the satellite town.

    The Majlis Haiah Dahwah which is a Sub-Committee of the MUIS dealing with matters on religion and education, will supervise and co-ordinate the religious, educational and cultural programmes of the mosques to ensure that such programmes meet the needs of Muslims in the area. Close liaison with the Mosque Management Committees will be maintained through the Honorary Secretary of each Committee who will be represented on the Majlis Haiah Dahwah. All Mosque Management Committees will be required to submit their mosque programmes to the Majlis for consideration. Periodical reports on the activities implemented together with financial reports of the mosques are also expected from the Committees.

    Funds are needed to maintain a large multi-purpose mosque. The MUIS on its part has set up a Mosque Maintenance Fund. For deserving cases, the MUIS will recommend the use of part of this Fund to help maintain and defray some expenses incurred by the Mosque Management Committees. However, the MUIS has no special allocation of funds to pay for the maintenance and management of all the new mosques. Mosque Management Committees should not expect everything to be paid for through the Mosque Building Fund collections or by the Majlis. I suggest that they continue with their fund-raising programmes to make the mosque building project a community effort with the active participation of all Muslim residents. The MUIS will issue licences as provided under section 73 of the Administration of Muslim Law Act to enable Mosque Management Committees to collect donations from Muslims to defray expenses such as salaries for Imams, Noja, Bilal, allowances for religious teachers and other

Column: 914

functions organised by Management Committees for the benefit of Muslims in the area.

BASIC COURSE AND JUNIOR TRAINEE SCHEME


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education whether facilities for vocational training are available to each and every student who is unable to complete primary or secondary education so that he or she will be given an opportunity to be trained in a useful trade.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Chai Chong Yii) (for the Minister for Home Affairs and Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, with the introduction of the Basic Course this year, pupils from the primary school system who are less academically inclined and unable to cope with the Standard Course are offered places in the Basic Course. The Basic Course is designed to provide such pupils with the opportunity to continue schooling up to a ninth year at primary level concentrating on the first language, a spoken second language, basic numeracy, arts and crafts and proper social and work attitudes. In addition, those in the final year of the Basic Course who have attained the age of 14 1/2 are provided with domestic science practice for the girls and workshop practice for the boys. Basic Course pupils will have the opportunity to go on to the Junior Trainee Scheme under which they can obtain on-the-job training. The Basic Course and Junior Trainee Scheme will therefore provide opportunities for vocational training to those leaving school at the primary level. Of the 4,376 pupils who failed the Primary School Leaving Examination last year and who were offered places in the Basic Course, a total of 3,450 accepted the offers and were enrolled.

    At the secondary level, there is presently no system for channelling those pupils who are unable or unlikely to complete the course with a minimum of 3 passes at `O' level in the General Certificate of Education examination. Some do, however, leave school on their own to seek employment or admission to

Column: 915

vocational courses conducted by the Industrial Training Board or the Adult Education Board. The Ministry of Education is now studying a possible scheme, in consultation with the Industrial Training Board and the Adult Education Board, under which pupils in the secondary school system who are unable or unlikely to complete the course with a minimum of 3 `O' level passes in the GCE examination could be channelled into vocational training to be provided by the ITB and the AEB. When such a scheme is introduced as a follow-up of what is now being practised in the primary school system, both the ITB and the AEB would have to increase their intake capacities for vocational courses. Presently, the ITB can take in a total of about 7,500 per year for such training and the AEB a total of about 3,000. Additional facilities will be added to meet the need if necessary.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, could the Senior Minister of State for Education enlighten this House as to when such a scheme could be implemented since the feasibility studies are being carried out by his Ministry now?

    Mr Chai Chong Yii: Sir, if everything goes on smoothly, it may be next year.

CHANGI VILLAGE
(Development as a tourist resort)


    3. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Finance whether it is planned to develop Changi Village as a tourist stopover point in view of its close proximity to the Changi International Airport.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to the Member for Changi's question is a definite "Yes". The Member would have noticed that Changi Village has been redeveloped into a modern complex consisting of shops, flats, a hawker centre and a market, all set in a landscaped site bordering the sea with a pedestrian mall, bandstand and shady trees.

Column: 916



    The Singapore Tourist Promotion Board is organising an East Coast Tour covering visits to Changi Village, Selarang Barracks, Changi Prison, East Coast Lagoon and possibly a visit to a kelong. At Changi Village, tourists will be able to do shopping and enjoy cool drinks and hawkers' food under open-air kiosks. Historical pictures with write-ups of the history of Changi Prison and Selarang Barracks will be sold. Visitors, particularly British and Australian servicemen who have served in Singapore, and their families, may find Changi a nostalgic place worth a visit.

MINISTRY OF FINANCE
(Implementation of new budget system)


    4. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for Finance what difficulties are envisaged in the implementation of the new Budget System and what measures are being or will be taken to ensure that the system is implemented smoothly.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, the new budgetary system will be a major departure from the present. It will naturally pose a number of problems in its implementation but these are likely to be mainly on orienting the civil service towards performance criteria in estimating and expenditure.

    The new system will do away with the present preoccupation on "things to be bought" and emphasise "the things to be done". The Budget will be framed to show each Ministry's programme, that is, what it intends to do. All expenditure items under each programme will be arranged according to projects and activities. Since each programme will constitute a separate subhead, Ministries will have great flexibility to reallocate expenditure within each programme to make the best possible use of the funds to achieve the objectives of the programme.

    However, all this implies that in estimating expenditure requirements, Ministries submit proposals on the basis of performance. For example, for road construction, estimates will have to be based on the total length of roads

Column: 917

to be built and the cost per unit run and how these compare against past costs and achievements and what the targets for the new year represent in the Ministry's total 5-year plan and other costs and benefits data.

    On the expenditure side, Ministries will have to monitor expenditure from the point of view of results and whether alternative means cannot be found to cut costs and improve, productivity. Because there will be greater flexibility, there will be less delays in changing the nature and content of expenditures to meet changed conditions. For example, within the constraints of their manpower budget, each Ministry will be able to employ more staff or less staff on a particular programme if conditions require this.

    Needless to say, these changes will require quite radical changes in the mental attitude of the civil service. There will have to be a greater awareness of cost-benefit and cost-effective criteria. There will have to be a greater emphasis on the correlation of financial requirements with objectives and targets. The civil service will have to develop performance indicators, norms, standards and historical data for estimating budgetary requirements. For actual expenditure the civil service will have to find effective ways of achieving the objectives or targets of their Ministry's programmes. Finally, at the end of the financial year, performance will have to be measured and evaluated. The evaluation of performance (the performance annual review) will be an integral part of the budgetary system, because this will enable the assessment to be made for the following year of the size of funds to be allocated on the basis of performance. In view of the nature and complexity of Government activities, much effort will be required to devise systems of measurement and refinements of performance indicators and norms as well as procedures for evaluation and assessment. Action has already been taken to explain to the civil service the new system and to train those officers directly involved in the budgetary process in the Ministries and Departments. The first rounds of discussions and talks involved recasting FY

Column: 918



1976    Budget into the new format. Numerous sessions were held to explain the principles and concepts involved. The major problems and difficulties associated with the system have been identified and in the second and third rounds of discussions, solutions and various compromises were worked out. When the FY 77 Budget has been approved, a similar exercise will be done to recast it into the new format. This will give the civil service further experience with the new system and hopefully enable the framing of the FY 78 Budget to be made properly and in time for the next financial year.

DOUBLE TAXATION AGREEMENTS
(Assessment of benefits)


    5. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Finance what benefits Singapore has derived from the many double taxation agreements concluded with other countries; how are the benefits assessed; and whether a similar agreement will be concluded with Indonesia.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, it is easy to understand that the inflow of funds, investments and technical expertise to Singapore from another country would be greatly discouraged if full taxes have to be paid according to the laws of both countries. In the absence of any agreement otherwise, income which arises and is taxed in Singapore and is then remitted home by a foreign company would still be subject to tax in its own country. At prevailing income tax rates, such cumulative taxation by two countries would be prohibitive. It would completely deter foreign investment in Singapore. The converse is also true for Singapore companies which have plans for substantial investments overseas.

    In bilateral tax treaties to avoid this situation, double taxation is eliminated through full or partial tax credit or exemption on interests, royalties, dividends, etc.

    Another important feature found in bilateral tax treaties between Singapore and the developed countries is "tax sparing". This is a means of ensuring that the tax on the

Column: 919

profits of foreign-owned companies foregone by the Government through various tax incentive measures is "spared" from tax by the foreign government. Without such bilateral treaties, incentives such as tax holiday benefits granted to such companies could be nullified if the foreign country should unilaterally decide to increase its tax by an amount equivalent to the tax remitted by the Singapore Government as a tax incentive.

    Besides the avoidance of double taxation, tax treaties also contribute to the prevention of fiscal evasion. As a company's books and records in one country are generally not available to another country, effective control is only possible if the two countries agree on the exchange of information. Tax treaties therefore invariably have provisions for the prevention of tax evasion and for the exchange of fiscal information.

    We have concluded avoidance of double taxation agreements with all the major EEC countries and Japan. In ASEAN, agreements with Thailand and Malaysia are in force, while an agreement with the Philippines was recently initialled.

    There is no simple method of assessing the benefits which Singapore derives from the conclusion of avoidance of double taxation agreements, but it is significant to note that it was only after the conclusion of tax treaties with Germany. Netherlands and Japan that big multi-national corporations from these three countries such as Rollei, Philips and Mitsubishi established themselves in Singapore in response to the various tax incentive measures granted by the Government. The tax treaties with these countries ensure that these benefits are not eroded through increased taxation by the home countries. Rollei Singapore Private Limited has invested $106 million, Philips Singapore Private Limited $45 million and Mitsubishi Singapore Heavy Industries Private Limited $110 million as at June 1976.

Column: 920



    The principal benefits flowing from tax treaties are the encouragement of the inflow of capital and technical expertise. In the process, local technical and managerial skills are upgraded and more employment opportunities are provided.

    Preliminary discussions were held in Djakarta in November 1973, on a Double Taxation Agreement between Singapore and Indonesia. An Indonesian team is expected to come to Singapore for the next round of negotiations, but the date has not been fixed. We would welcome an early agreement with Indonesia as this would contribute to expansion of intra-ASEAN trade and would encourage greater investments among member states. However, pending the conclusion of a tax treaty with Indonesia, Singapore grants exemption from tax on income derived from certain approved Singapore investments in Indonesia which enjoy pioneer status or tax holidays in Indonesia.

SINGAPORE AIRPORT DUTY-FREE EMPORIUM
(Sale of Government's equity)


    6. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Finance what is the rationale behind the sale of 31 per cent of the Government's equity holding in Singapore Airport Duty-Free Emporium Private Limited to Singapore Airlines Limited; and what are the benefits to the Government from that transaction.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I do not consider it appropriate, as a rule, that I should be called upon to explain operational decisions on investments, particularly where they involve transactions between one Government company and another. I shall, however, make an exception in this case.

    Singapore Airport Duty-Free Emporium was set up in October 1974 as a joint venture between the Government, Singapore Airlines, and Singapore Airport Terminal Services. SIA is owned by the Singapore Government while SATS is owned by SIA. The joint venture company is therefore essentially a Government company. The

Column: 921

Government's shares in both SIA and SADE are now held by Temasek Holdings (Pte) Ltd, which is a Government company.

    In March last year the SIA Group suggested that its stake in SADE should be increased to reflect more closely its major involvement in SADE's operations:

    1. The Group was managing the company.

    2. SIA was promoting SADE not only in its ticketing outlets in Singapore but throughout its network.

    3. SIA would prefer to sell duty-free goods at the Airport than on board its aircraft.

    This was agreed, and after negotiations, a suitable transfer price was agreed.

    The benefits to Government from the transaction are presumably that credit is given where credit is due, higher profits accruing to the organisation striving to promote increased business.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, will the Minister please inform the House, as a matter of principle why should he make an exception in this particular case?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, the object of this exception is to inform Members that, in operational details, there is really no purpose in the House enquiring nor is there any purpose in the Minister enquiring why in a particular company, the SIA, for example, chooses Boeing 727 instead of the Airbus. This is a matter of commercial judgment and the details are best left to the company concerned. The Minister would himself not be in a position to make any better judgment nor would the Members of this House if the details were known.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, who are the owners of all these monies belonging to all those companies?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: The Minister for Finance is ultimately the owner. This is a corporation which is enacted under an Act of Parliament, so that ultimately the Singapore Government is the owner of all the monies of all the Government companies.

Column: 922



    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, would the Minister not agree that since we are all representatives of the people, and the people own the money, but which the Minister alleged that he owns them, are `we not shareholders in all these companies?

    Mr Hon Sui San: I agree entirely that the people of Singapore, including Members of Parliament, are shareholders in the Government companies. But as to the process of enquiring into the operations, I think the shareholders of companies are not really asked at annual general meetings to consider whether, in fact, SIA or any other company has made a good commercial judgment in, say, using Sulzer Diesel Engines rather than Burmeister and Wain Diesel Engines, or whether they should buy a Boeing 727 rather than an Airbus. I can see no connection between shareholding and enquiries into operational details.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Is the Minister suggesting or implying that Members may raise questions concerning policy matters relating to all these companies and not day-to-day administrative matters?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Certainly. All matters of policy are the concern of the Minister for Finance and consequently, since he is accountable to Parliament. he is accountable to Members of Parliament.

CULTURAL SHOWS
(Exemption from entertainment duty)


    7. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Finance what are the criteria for exemption of cultural shows from entertainments duty; and whether he will revise the criteria to encourage more cultural shows with local content to be staged in Singapore.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, briefly where shows are organised for profits and not for charitable, philanthropic, educational or sporting purposes, entertainments duty exemption is a discretionary matter but will generally be granted to performances of intrinsic cultural value. It is difficult to define

Column: 923

precisely what shows are of cultural value. Exemptions have, however, been granted to such performances as symphonic concerts, chamber music ensembles, operas, ballets, plays and national cultural shows. Other factors that have been taken into consideration are whether the artistes are of international status and whether the performances would attract a reasonably large public audience. The unduly esoteric or the mundane will not normally qualify for exemption.

    As regards encouragement of more cultural shows of local content, my Ministry has granted exemption from entertainments duty to shows and performances presented, sponsored or organised by such organisations as the National Theatre Trust, the People's Association and the Kreta Ayer People's Theatre Foundation. Favourable consideration will continue to be given to applications for exemption from entertainments duty on shows and performances displaying the various facets of our rich multi-cultural heritage.

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    The Chairman: Main and Development Estimates of Singapore for the financial year 1st April, 1977 to 31st March, 1978, contained in Paper Cmd. 3 of 1977. For convenience. I shall take the totals for each head of expenditure in the Main Estimates and the Development Estimates as they appear in the fifth and sixth columns respectively of the Summary of Estimated Expenditure on page 43 of the Paper.

    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Head K -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, That the sum to be allocated for Head K be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1002*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs P. Govindaswamy, Ivan Baptist and Dr Ong Leong Boon.)

    Sir, the Main and Development Estimates allocation for the Ministry of Defence amounts to $908 million. This is a good portion of the total budget provision. Of course, we know that it is important to build our defence capability for our security. For a young and newly emergent country like ours, it is all the more necessary to consolidate our defence so as to protect our independence and territorial integrity.

    So far, our national service scheme has been successful, However, as regards training, whether it is proper and adequate and whether our servicemen are being trained to be good soldiers and of good quality are matters for the authority concerned and the officers in charge to exercise constant review.

    In the past, I believe we have all heard of unpleasant incidents taking place in the camps or barracks. There were instances where soldiers and officers have quarrelled, leading to tragedy. There was such an incident not long ago where a soldier, because of personal affairs, had gone beyond the bounds of a soldier, Although such

Column: 925

instances are rare, it is a matter that worries us. My question is: after two years of military life in the camps whether these youngsters have been taught the proper attitudes towards life, personal behaviour, good discipline, and a civic sense so that they are more disciplined, more matured and better behaved. This is a very important matter that merits the serious attention of all concerned.

    I would like to raise three questions to the Minister. First, will the Minister consider abolishing the decision to enlist women into national service, although the actual date has not been fixed? As it is now, we are able to recruit women by the "voluntary and open method". So is it, therefore, necessary for us to conscript our women? I am not a male chauvinist or under-estimating the capacity of our women and girls, but there is nearly a thousand years' history about women's role in military activities. I am sure you have heard of Hua Mu Lan, a girl in ancient China.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, it is not the policy of the Government during this financial year to recruit women into the NSF, nor is there any money provided for such enlistment. Under these circumstances, would the Member be in order to raise this matter which is not provided for in the budget?

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): In that case, I will not touch on it. I think the Minister was perhaps not prepared as to how to answer my question.

    Let me raise the second question. It relates to consideration for exemption from national service for those whose families are in financial difficulty. For instance, if the only son in the family is the sole breadwinner, or in the case where two or three brothers are being enlisted at the same time, there should be some arrangement where they can be enlisted for national service consecutively in order to help them in their financial difficulties.

    In my meet-the-people sessions in the past I have also been asked to request the Ministry concerned to allow them to opt for part-time police national service, so that for

Column: 926

the period of their obligation these youngsters could help their family by earning some money. Some such applications have been rejected which act, I feel. was too stringent or not quite humane. So I would like to ask the Minister to ask the Advisory Committee to exercise more sympathetic consideration for such petitions. Although the Committee comprises representatives from the various quarters of our society, including the industry, public service, higher institutions of learning, and professional circles, I think it would be better to include representatives from the Social Welfare Department as they understand better the plight of a poor family and so can provide the Committee with better grounds for a more sympathetic and proper consideration. What does the Minister think about this?

    The third question I would like to raise is about drug-taking incidents in the camps. This is a very serious matter. I would like to ask how many cases of drug-taking have been discovered in the past few years and what measures or action have been taken by the military or camp authority to eliminate this abuse?

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, national service was introduced sometime in 1967. During the initial period a few batches of recruits were sent to the 1st SIR for three months training and were absorbed into the People's Defence Force. Subsequently, after a couple of years when they were performing part-time service, some of these recruits were transferred to the Special Constabulary. There is a standing instruction saying that those affected by national service must compulsorily perform part-time national service for 12 years or until they reach 40 years of age, whichever is the later after having completed full-time national service. I have received complaints from many national service reservists, who had been transferred to the Special Constabulary, that they were told that the period reckoned for part-time national service would commence from the time they were transferred to the Special Constabulary. Can the Minister enlighten the House on this point?

Column: 927



    I also understand that there are rumours that the part-time performance of reservists who have reached the age of 40 years has been abolished. Is this true? Could the Minister clarify this point?

    Sir, I wonder whether exemption from part-time national service would be considered for a person who has passed the call-up age but who is called up because of his employment in the civil service.

    There is the case of a person who wrote to the Central Manpower Base that he had served in the Special Constabulary for a period of six years from 1962 to 1968 and that he had undergone all the basic police training at the Police Academy and that he was in active service during the riots, the civil disturbances and other emergencies during that time. However, due to pressure of shift duties and private studies, he was unable to continue service with the Special Constabulary and he ultimately resigned in 1968. Currently, he is working in a statutory board where his presence is required in times of emergency. Besides having to work on shift duties, he is also pursuing private studies for a promotion. Therefore, he would like to know whether consideration would be given for his past performance. I wonder whether an exception could be made for such cases.

    There is another case of a breadwinner of a family who passed away recently. The widow, a housewife now has to look after five children. The eldest-son has been serving full-time national service for the last one year. Can consideration be given for the boy to be discharged from national service, so that he could seek employment to help the family financially? Can the Minister reply to this?

    Sir, parents have now more or less accepted the concept of national service. But then I have received numerous complaints from parents that their boys have been spoilt after being enlisted for national service. Many of them indulge in undesirable habits like drinking and smoking which they never

Column: 928

knew before they were called up. The Minister may blame the parents for their sons' behaviour. But then we cannot expect the parents to know what is actually happening in the camps. I understand that drinks and cigarettes are sold cheaply in the camps and this could be the reason why the boys indulge in these bad habits. When I say "bad habits". I do not mean that an individual should not drink or smoke. I believe that acquiring these habits at a very young age, and especially in the army, could be considered as anti-social. Basically, even the Government does not encourage these habits and here in the army we find our youths merrily drinking and smoking.
